dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, leadership is just, uh, telling people what to do, right? You're the boss, you just give orders and they follow them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, leadership is just, uh, telling people what to do, right? You're the boss, you just give orders and they follow them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A great leader is a teacher and a coach, not a dictator.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, whoa there. Not exactly. I mean, that's, uh, that's management. Leadership is actually a whole different ballgame.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, whoa there. Not exactly. I mean, that's, uh, that's management. Leadership is actually a whole different ballgame.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Think of leadership as next level management. The best leaders take their expert management skills and combine them with people skills to become well rounded and highly successful.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Really? But... isn't that kinda the same thing? Like, you're still in charge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Really? But... isn't that kinda the same thing? Like, you're still in charge.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, yeah, but great leaders, they don't just direct. They, uh, they coach. They mentor. It's more about developing your team, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, yeah, but great leaders, they don't just direct. They, uh, they coach. They mentor. It's more about developing your team, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A great leader is a teacher and a coach, not a dictator. They help their teams develop and grow, and support them by providing training in various forms, including coaching and mentoring.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, coaching, not directing. So, like, I shouldn't just tell them what to do if things, uh, go wrong?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, coaching, not directing. So, like, I shouldn't just tell them what to do if things, uh, go wrong?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. You gotta be adept. Anticipate change, respond quickly. Sometimes that's empowering them to solve it, not just you, like, jumping in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. You gotta be adept. Anticipate change, respond quickly. Sometimes that's empowering them to solve it, not just you, like, jumping in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Being adept. Great leaders are prepared for change to happen at any time. Theyre able to think and make decisions quickly, and more importantly, they know how to rally their teams to make results happen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But what if they, like, need me to jump in? To make sure they're doing it right? I feel like I'd just, uh, micromanage everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But what if they, like, need me to jump in? To make sure they're doing it right? I feel like I'd just, uh, micromanage everything.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And that's where respect comes in, actually. You gotta trust your team. Micromanaging, uh, it actually signals a lack of faith.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that's where respect comes in, actually. You gotta trust your team. Micromanaging, uh, it actually signals a lack of faith.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No employee likes to be micromanaged, as it indicates to them that you don't trust their abilities. In fact, its one of the quickest ways to lose respect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, I just let them, like, fail then? That feels, uh, risky.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, I just let them, like, fail then? That feels, uh, risky.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not fail, necessarily. It's about letting them take calculated risks. And, uh, accepting occasional setbacks. It's how they learn, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not fail, necessarily. It's about letting them take calculated risks. And, uh, accepting occasional setbacks. It's how they learn, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Leaders must allow their employees to take risks and accept that they will fail sometimes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. Okay. So, what about communication? Like, just being clear, I guess?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. Okay. So, what about communication? Like, just being clear, I guess?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, it's so much more than just being clear. You have to be a master communicator. Like, adapting your style for every situation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, it's so much more than just being clear. You have to be a master communicator. Like, adapting your style for every situation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Great leaders can tailor their communication style to meet the needs of any situation. A leader must be an excellent listener, in order to truly understand the needs of their team. Great leaders understand that different situations call for different communication styles, and are able to switch between them with ease.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Adapting? So, I, uh, talk differently to different people?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Adapting? So, I, uh, talk differently to different people?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! Sometimes you're advising, sometimes you're just listening, sometimes you're motivating. It's, um, it's all about versatility.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! Sometimes you're advising, sometimes you're just listening, sometimes you're motivating. It's, um, it's all about versatility.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There are six key communication styles you should be familiar with - listening, advising, directing, motivating, teaching, and coaching.
